Fig. 1 Top view of the structure of the Fe@MoS2. (P1: Fe on Mo top site, P2: Fe on S top site, P3: Fe on VS site, P4: Fe on hollow site). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The optimized structures. (a) Fe@MoS2 monatomic catalyst; (b) phenol molecule. (Bluish violet: Fe, Cyan: Mo, Yellow: S, Gray: C, Red: O, White: H). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The PDOS of (a) pristine MoS2 and (b) Fe@MoS2. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Optimized structures of the adsorption and dissociation of H2. (a) H2 on S atop; (b) H-H on S; (c) H-H on Fe and S. (Bluish violet: Fe, Cyan: Mo, Yellow: S, White: H). Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a fundamental process for bio-oil upgrading. The implementation at the commercial scale of this technology, however, is limited by the development of catalysts. This study presents MoS2-supported single-atom Fe (Fe@MoS2) catalyst for bio-oil HDO. The geometry structures, adsorption behaviors, and deoxygenation process of phenol on the Fe@MoS2 surface are studied using Density Functional Theory (DFT). We investigated six possible reaction pathways involving almost all elementary reactions to provide an in-depth description of phenol deoxygenation that produce benzene and water on the Fe@MoS2 surface. By systemically comparing the reaction energy barriers, the best deoxygenation pathway is obtained, whose mechanism is partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration, i.e. PHDO2. In addition, we found that Fe anchored at S vacancy is more favorite to absorb and active phenol. It is expected that our research can make quite a few contributions to bio-oil upgrading. Graphical abstract MoS2 supported single-atom Fe catalyst for phenol hydrodeoxygenation was designed, and phenol's adsorption behavior and deoxygenation process were studied by density functional theory. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phenol Hydrodeoxygenation mechanism Density functional theory Adsorption behavior Single-atom catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Obtaining chemical fuels by energy conversion is a broader strategy for solving oil shortages and environmental problems. Hence substantial research has been carried out to find alternative fuels [1–7]. Biomass, the most earth-abundant substances, is a promising sustainable energy resource which is expected to reduce dependence on fossil fuels and minimize CO2 emissions [8,9]. Tuning biomass into high-grad liquid fuel, however, is not easy. One prospective way is to convert biomass into bio-oil through flash pyrolysis first and then upgrade it with a catalyst [10,11]. The main ingredients in pyrolysis bio-oil are biomass-derived phenolic compounds. Therefore, the critical question in the upgrade section is to reduce oxygen content [12,13]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) technology is a desirable method for bio-oil upgrading in which the phenolic compounds are converted into valuable hydrocarbons selectively. Currently, a major challenge in HDO is how to boost the performance of catalysts [14]. Compared with traditional metal bulks or nanoparticles, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have shown strong catalytic performance ability because the metal's atomic efficiency is maximized and unexpected catalytic activity and selectivity are obtained [15–17]. Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) has unsaturated Mo and S atoms at the edges, which can provide favorable edge activity [18]. Therefore, Mo-based sulfides promoted by Co or Ni become well-known hydrotreating catalysts. The isolated Co atom on monolayer MoS2 has been stated to be a potential catalyst for HDO of phenol [19]. A surface atomic engineering strategy aimed at obtaining well-dispersed Co-incorporated MoS2 nanomaterial are proposed, which brings high activity for catalyzing HDO reaction of lignin-derived phenolic compounds [20,21]. Similarly, Ni-promoted MoS2 catalysts have been widely studied for HDO. It has been reported that the presence of Ni may change the selectivity of HDO and Ni has a significant promoting effect on MoS2 in NiMoS structure [22]. Further studies about the promoting effect of transition metals on MoS2/γ-Al2O3 were developed [23]. They found the HDO activity and selectivity of transition metals on MoS2 related to the metal properties and reaction products. In fact, the catalytic mechanism is usually terribly complicated. By systematically studying the possible route, the mechanism of Co-MoS2 catalyze HDO reaction of phenolic compounds is revealed [21]. The demand for catalysts to reduce oxygen content in bio-oil upgrading is rising. Transition metals usually have empty d orbits that can be used as electron-philic potential points, which contribute to their adsorption and activation of the critical reaction intermediate [24]. Among them, Fe is the cheapest metal on the earth. Unfortunately, Fe seems to be forgotten, which may be due to its low promotion effect on molybdenum disulfide for HDS [25]. Actually, Fe catalyst exhibits particular selectivity for CAr-O bond cleavage, enhancing aromatic products' production. The role Fe plays in the catalyst is oxophilic center, which forms strong bonds with oxygen functional groups and promotes the rupture of CAr-O bonds [26–28]. In addition, it has been reported that the doping of Fe can promote the catalytic activity of the MoS2 plane [29]. However, the determination of the active center in Fe-promoted MoS2 catalyst and the mechanism of hydrodeoxygenation of phenolic compounds are still uncertain. And that's why we pursue this research. In this study, the MoS2-supported single-atom Fe (Fe@MoS2) catalyst was designed, on which the adsorption behaviors and the HDO reaction mechanism of phenol were studied in detail by using DFT. 2 Model and calculation method MoS2 monomolecular layer was constructed by using Material Studio software. Based on the cell (d (Mo-S) = 2.41 nm, φ (S-Mo-S) = φ (Mo-S-Mo) = 81.82°, lattice constant = 3.17 nm), a crystal in the p(4 × 4) supercell was constructed, which contains 32 S and 16 Mo atoms and is illustrated in Fig. S1. The lattice constant of the MoS2 slab constructed is 12.69 × 12.69 × 18.4 Å. The vacuum region at the top is large enough to avoid interactions between adjacent cells. All calculated results provided herein were performed using spin-polarized density-functional theory methods implemented in the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [30,31]. The electron-ion interactions and exchange-correlation interactions were treated by the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) [32,33] functional. Based on Monkhorst-Pack scheme, the Brillouin region was sampled with 3 × 3 × 1 K-mesh and a cutoff energy of 400 eV for plane wave basis set were adopted. The climbing image nudged elastic band (Cl-NEB) method and Dimer method was used for searching transition states (TSs), and each transition state was verified to have only one virtual vibration frequency along the reaction coordinate direction [34]. The adsorption energy ( E a d s ) of the surface species is defined by (1) E a d s = E m o l e c u l e + s u r f a c e − E a d s o r b a t e − E b a r e s u r f a c e Among them, E m o l e c u l e + s u r f a c e represents the total energy of adsorbent adsorbed on the catalyst substrate, E a d s o r b a t e represents the energy of adsorbent in the gas phase, and E b a r e s u r f a c e represents the energy of catalyst substrate. If the adsorption energy is positive, it indicates that the adsorption process is endothermic, while the negative value is exothermic. What's more, the more negative E a d s , the stronger the interaction between the catalyst surface and the adsorbed molecule [35]. The activation energy barrier ( E a c t ) of primitive reaction is calculated by (2) E act = E T S − E I S Where E T S and E I S are the energy of the transition state and the adsorbed state of the reactive material in the definite elementary reaction step. The reaction energy ( E r x n ) in the elemental reaction is calculated by the formula (3) E r x n = E F S − E I S Where E F S is the energy of the formed product adsorbed on the catalyst surface. According to the calculated absorption energy ( E a d s ), reaction energy ( E r x n ) and activation energy barrier ( E a c t ), the energy pathway of HDO reaction of phenol on the Fe@MoS2 surface was drawn. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures and properties of Fe@MoS2 and phenol In order to gain a stable catalyst, almost all of the possible geometrical structures of the Fe@MoS2 basal plane were optimized (Fig. S1). Compared to S vacancy, the Mo vacancy creating requires more energy (see Table S1). Furthermore, to balance the charge caused by the substitution of Fe (2+) for Mo (4+), additional S vacancy is needed, and as a result, adds a further energy. Therefore, four main Fe anchored sites in the basal plane of MoS2 were considered (see Fig. 1 ), they are top of Mo site (namely Fe on Mo top site), top of S site (namely Fe on S top site), vacancy of S site (namely Fe on VS site), and hollow site (namely Fe on hollow site). By systemically comparing the formation energy (see Table S1), we preliminarily located the S vacancy as anchor site. The energy barrier of −3.65 eV ensures that Fe atoms cannot aggregate into clusters. Further studies about the stability of Fe atom are provided in Fig S2. S vacancy can kinetically trap the Fe atom with a large migration barrier of 1.65 eV, suggesting that the S vacancy can firmly anchor the Fe atom. Furthermore, as it's shown in Fig. 2 a, the bond angles of Mo-Fe-Mo and S-Mo-Fe of Fe@MoS2 are slightly changed to 75.27° and 76.71°, while the perfect monolayer MoS2 is 81.80°, indicating that the substituted doping of Fe slightly changes the geometry of MoS2. To get further insight into the interaction mechanism between Fe and MoS2, the projected density of states (PDOS) were calculated, as displayed in Fig. 3 . After anchoring, the DOS distribution near the Fermi energy level changes significantly. Therefore, the new hybridized orbitals near the Fermi energy level can be used as catalytic reaction active sites. The spin-up is mainly contributed by the d orbital of the Fe atom, while the spin-down is maily contributed by the d orbitals of Mo (see Fig. 3b), indicating that the Fe atom's introduction changes the electronic properties of MoS2. What's more, as shown in Fig. S3, for the pristine MoS2, the adsorption of phenol is mainly contributed by the hybridization of S, Mo, C, while for the Fe@MoS2, the additional orbital interaction of Fe with C and Fe with O were introduced. These PDOS results mean that the anchoring of Fe is beneficial to the adsorption and activation of phenol. Herein, phenol was selected as a model compound to assess the value of the catalyst because of the bond dissociation energy sequence (Caromatic-OH > Caromatic-OC > CaromaticOC [36]). The structure of phenol was optimized by using the same method. As shown in Fig. 2b, the bond length of CAr−O and O−H are 1.38 and 0.98 Å, respectively. And the bond angle of the CAr−O−H is 108.95°, which is consistent with existing experimental and theoretical calculations [37]. 3.2 Adsorption and activation behavior of H2 and phenol on the surface of Fe@MoS2 monatomic catalyst 3.2.1 Adsorption and dissociation of H2 In this part, the adsorption and dissociation of H2 on the surface of the Fe@MoS2 monatomic catalyst will be discussed. The adsorption sites, namely H2 adsorption on Fe atop (H2 on Fe), H2 adsorption on S edge atop (H2 on S edge) and H2 adsorption on S atop adjacent to Fe (H2 on S atop), were investigated respectively, as illustrated in Fig. S4. The adsorption energies and the bond length of H-H are listed in Table 1 . H2 is physisorptions to Fe atom (see Fig. S4a), and the adsorption energy is 0.31 eV. The interatomic distance of HH increases from 0.75 Å in the gas phase to 0.84 Å in the adsorption state. However, this adsorption manner of H2 can not be dissociated into two H atoms. The other two adsorption manners are both physical adsorptions. And the better site for H2 adsorption is the edge of MoS2, which is consistent with previous research [38]. In addition, their adsorption energies converge to 0 eV, which favors the adsorption and dissociation of H2. Fig. 4 a displayed the molecularly adsorbed H2, and it can dissociate into two H atoms that share one S atom (namely H-H on S, see Fig. 4b). This process needs overcome 1.02 eV energy barrier, and the desorption adsorption energy of H2 is −1.77 eV (see Fig. S5). In addition, the dissociated H atoms adsorbed on S can easily migrate to the Fe atom and form a more stable adsorption structure (namely HH on Fe and S, see Fig. 4c) with adsorption energy of −3.52 eV. And this migration energy barrier is about 0.05 eV (see Fig. S6), indicating that H2 is easily activated and dissociated on the catalyst surface. Besides, the dissociated H atoms can provide the HDO reaction with active H. 3.2.2 Adsorption and activation of phenol In order to get a clear understanding of the HDO reaction mechanism of phenol on Fe@MoS2 catalysts, the adsorption and activation characteristics of reactants were investigated. Here, we mainly consider two possible adsorption modes, namely vertical adsorption (i.e., V mode) and horizontal adsorption (i.e., H mode). Different orientations and different locations of phenol adsorption on the catalyst surface were adopt to obtain the optimal adsorption configuration (Fig. S7). Fig. S8 shows the optimal adsorption configuration for the two possible adsorption modes. The parameters associated with the two configurations were listed in Table 2 . From Table 2, we found that the chemisorption of phenol is exothermic for both adsorption models, and the adsorption energy of −1.53 eV and −0.67 eV are observed, respectively. As mentioned earlier, the more negative E a d s , the stronger the interaction between the catalyst surface and the adsorbed molecule. Therefore, the more negative adsorption energy of phenol with V mode indicated that the adsorption of V mode was stronger. Besides, the most favorable configuration was shown in Fig. 5 a and 5b. In fact, benzene is not exactly perpendicular to the surface but has a certain inclination to the surface, about 66.04°, and the bond length of CAr-O and O−H are slightly elongated to 1.41 and 0.99 Å, respectively (see Fig. 5a). Further, the bond angle of C-O-H slightly increased to 130.78° (see Fig. 5b). The main reason for these changes may be attributed to the strong interaction between the -OH group and the oxophilic Fe atom. For pristine MoS2, however, phenol was horizontally adsorbed on its surface (see Fig. 5c). To further understand the interaction between phenol and Fe@MoS2, the electron density and Bader charge were calculated. As shown in Fig. 6 , the phenol on Fe@MoS2 exhibits more charge transfer than on pristine MoS2. Therefore, the strong interaction between phenol and oxophilic Fe atom results in the length of the CAr-O and O-H bonds being elongated, which benefits the activation and cracking of CAr-O. The Bader charge change for phenol adsorption on pristine MoS2 and Fe@MoS2 surfaces are 0.03 and 0.10 electrons, respectively, indicating that phenol obtained more electrons from Fe@MoS2, which is consistent with the geometric analysis mentioned above. In brief, the doped Fe atom is the active site for phenol adsorption, and vertical adsorption mode is more favorable for the activation and cleavage of CAr-O. 3.3 Reaction pathway of phenol HDO on Fe@MoS2 surface Two reaction pathways are prevalent in the HDO reactions of phenolic model compounds: one is deoxygenation after complete hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, and the other is direct deoxygenation with retention of the aromatic ring. In this study, our eyes were focused on two reaction pathways, namely direct deoxygenation (DDO) and partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration (PHDO), aimed at obtaining the target products that retain aromatic rings. 3.3.1 Direct deoxygenation The DDO reaction of phenol was investigated from the most stable adsorption configuration. The energy changes and optimized structures of phenol on Fe@MoS2 surface were presented in Fig. 7 . Firstly, gaseous C6H5OH molecule is adsorbed on the Fe@MoS2 surface. Secondly, the adsorbed C6H5OH is decomposed into C6H5 fragment and OH species through transition state (C6H5OH*→C6H5*+OH*, see Fig. 7a). The activation energy barrier and reaction heat are 1.43 eV and 0.64 eV, respectively. Meanwhile, the distance between C atom and O atom increases gradually (1.41 Å → 1.89 Å → 2.57 Å, see Fig. 7a). In addition, a new small vacancy was formed during the formation of transition state because of the slightly shift in the position of Fe atom. Compared to the initial adsorption configuration, the phenyl rotates slightly and become more perpendicular to the surface of catalyst. In the final state, the CAr-O bond is cleaved. The OH*, then, is stabilized on the top of the small vacancy created by the Fe atom. It should be noted that the structure of C6H5* intermediate in the final state does not differ much from that in the transition state. Subsequently, the adsorbed C6H5* intermediate is coordinated with H atom to form C6H6 molecule via C6H5*+H*→C6H6*, as shown in Fig. 7b. In this reaction, the surface H*which shares the same adsorption site as OH* in the dehydrogenated final state, moves gradually toward the benzene ring. The distance between the C and H atoms gradually decreases (2.27 Å → 2.06 Å → 1.14 Å). When the d C − H distance is 2.06 Å, a stable phenyl hydrogenated transition state is formed. The formation of C6H6 is an exothermic reaction with energy barrier of 0.26 eV and reaction heat of 0.75 eV. Here, we define this reaction as DDO1. Another elementary reaction step for C6H6 formation is C6H5*+OH*→C6H6*+ O*, as illustrated in Fig. S9. In this reaction process, the adsorbed C6H5 strips an H from the OH fragment through transition state, leaving an O atom stably adsorbed in the void created by the movement of the Fe atom. When the bond length of O-H is 1.13 Å and the distance between H and C atoms is 1.63 Å, a stable phenyl hydrogenated transition state is formed. The benzene is noted as the final product, which was adsorbed on the surface of catalyst in an inclined parallel manner. This reaction step is activated by 0.73 eV and exothermic by 0.42 eV. We define this pathway as DDO2. In addition, we have explored the hydrodeoxygenation of phenol to benzene through cracking O-H followed by breaking the CAr-O bond (defined as DDO3). The energy diagram and its optimized structures are shown in Fig. S10. In the first elementary reaction, the adsorbed C6H5OH* decomposes into C6H5O* fragment and H atom via C6H5OH*→C6H5O*+ H* with an activation energy barrier is 1.34 eV (see Fig. S10a). The second elementary reaction step of C6H6 (C6H5O*→C6H5*+ O*) is a slight exothermic process (0.43 eV) but with a high activation energy barrier (1.77 eV), as shown in Fig. S10b. In the hydrodeoxygenation mentioned above, the energy barriers for DDO1 are relatively low, indicating that the phenol can be readily turned into benzene. For DDO2, it needs to strip the H atom before hydrogenation, so it requires to overcome an additional energy barrier of 0.73 eV. As for DDO3, the high energy barrier (1.77 eV) in the second reaction step makes it more unachievable. Thus, it suggests that the optimal reaction pathway for converting phenol to benzene by direct hydrodeoxygenation is DDO1. 3.3.2 Partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration Here, three possible paths that obtain desirable product C6H6 from PHDO of phenol over Fe@MoS2 catalyst were considered. They are named PHDO1, PHDO2 and PHDO3, respectively. The energy diagram and optimized configurations of involved states in the way of PHDO1 are shown in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8a, C6H5OH* +H*→C6H5OH2* is the first possible elementary reaction step, through which the H atom hydrogenated the O atom of adsorbed C6H5OH to form the unstable C6H5OH2 species. And in this process, the H atom migrates from the surface Fe site to the O site of C6H5OH gradually (2.33 Å → 1.76 Å → 1.14 Å). This reaction is activated by 0.44 eV and is highly exothermic by 1.33 eV. The second elementary reaction step is C6H5OH2* dissociate via C6H5OH2*→C6H5*+H2O*. This reaction is an exothermic process with exothermicity of 1.46 eV and activation energy of 1.21 eV (see Fig. 8b). The following hydrogenation of the phenyl group is the same as that in direct dehydroxylation mentioned earlier. Compared with PHDO1, PHDO2 presents a relatively low activation energy barrier (see Fig. 9 ). As shown in Fig. 9a, C6H5OH*+H*→C6H6OH* is slightly exothermic by 0.12 eV and is activated by 0.89 eV. In this process, the dissociated H atom moves from the surface Fe to α-C (C1) of C6H5OH gradually (2.62 Å → 1.63 Å → 1.12 Å), and the distance was frozen at 1.63 Å in transition state. As for C6H6OH*→ C6H6*+OH*, the reaction is activated by 1.01 eV and endothermic by 0.30 eV (see Fig. 9b). During this reaction, the distance between the C atom and O atom increases gradually: 1.53 Å → 1.57 Å → 2.96 Å, which implied that the rupture of CAr-O was realized. Another possible reaction path of C6H6 formation is PHDO3, whose energy diagram and optimized configurations are shown in Fig. S11. Plainly, there are three elementary reaction steps. The first step is the hydrogenation of the adsorbed C6H5OH: C6H5OH*+H*→C6H6OH*, and the reaction is highly activated by 1.39 eV (see Fig. S11a). The cleavage of CAr-O happens in the second step: C6H6OH*→C6H6*+ OH* (see Fig. S11b). This reaction is an endothermic process with energy barrier of 1.26 eV and exothermicity of 0.56 eV. In the last step, the unsaturated hydroxyl C atom of C6H6*strips the excess H atom from the β-C (C2) atom to form benzene by surmounting activation energy barrier of 0.53 eV. Factoring in the stability of the intermediate and the energy barrier of reaction, the optimal way to convert phenol to benzene by partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration is PHDO2. Water is the by-product in the process of obtaining benzene from phenol, both DDO and PHDO. The energy diagram and optimized configurations are presented in Fig. S12. The H* atom on the surface migrates to the vacant site near the Fe atom, and the distance between the H atom and the hydroxyl-O is 3.16 Å. Subsequently, the H atom keeps approaching the O atom, and a stable transition state is formed when the distance between the O atom and H atom is 1.48 Å. This process requires overcoming an energy barrier of 0.69 eV, and eventually, OH and H form a bond with a bond length of 0.98 Å. Furthermore, the two optimal reaction paths mentioned above were summarized in Fig. 10 for contrast. On the Fe@MoS2 catalyst surface, the reaction energy for the conversion of phenol to benzene via DDO1 presents a high energy barrier of 1.43 eV, while for PHDO2, it is 1.01 eV. Therefore, the PHDO2 pathway shows more favorable energy. Besides, it has been established that pristine MoS2 can adsorb and activate phenol, and S vacancies can create more active sites on the MoS2 substrate, causing the MoS2 with S vacancies can better promote phenol adsorption and activation. At the meantime, previous results have shown that the reaction energy barrier for the direct dissociation of C-O bond from phenol on the MoS2 surface with S vacancies is 1.77 eV [21], which is a much higher energy barrier than that of the Fe@MoS2. And this further demonstrates that Fe@MoS2 is an excellent catalyst for phenol hydrodeoxygenation. 4 Conclusion The unique Fe@MoS2 catalyst is designed. Based on it, the reaction path for the hydrodeoxygenation reaction of phenol is proposed. The results indicated the most stable structure of Fe@MoS2 is Fe anchored at S vacancy, and the introduction of Fe into MoS2 catalyst resulted in the modification of electronic properties of MoS2, which facilitates the adsorption and activation of phenol as well as the formation of benzene. Besides, the adsorption of H2 and phenol were studied, the results demonstrated that H2 adsorption on Fe@MoS2 surface is physisorption while hydrogen atom (H) adsorption is chemisorption. Further studies demonstrated that the dissociated H atom can easily diffused on the surface, thus remaining the active H for HDO. As for phenol, it was chemisorbed on the Fe@MoS2 surface. In addition, six possible reaction pathways for direct deoxygenation and partial hydrogenation deoxygenation were examined, the results showed that the transformation of phenol into benzene via partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration route (PHDO2) is the most energetically favorable. Notably, in the process of CAr-O bond fracture, Fe's relative position changed, creating a small vacancy that could be used to capture the fractured OH group or O atom stably. Further studies along this line are ongoing. CRediT authorship contribution statement Hui Zhu: Conceptualization, Investigation, Formal analysis, Writing – original draft. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is a fundamental process for bio-oil upgrading. The implementation at the commercial scale of this technology, however, is limited by the development of catalysts. This study presents MoS2-supported single-atom Fe (Fe@MoS2) catalyst for bio-oil HDO. The geometry structures, adsorption behaviors, and deoxygenation process of phenol on the Fe@MoS2 surface are studied using Density Functional Theory (DFT). We investigated six possible reaction pathways involving almost all elementary reactions to provide an in-depth description of phenol deoxygenation that produce benzene and water on the Fe@MoS2 surface. By systemically comparing the reaction energy barriers, the best deoxygenation pathway is obtained, whose mechanism is partial hydrogenation followed by dehydration, i.e. PHDO2. In addition, we found that Fe anchored at S vacancy is more favorite to absorb and active phenol. It is expected that our research can make quite a few contributions to bio-oil upgrading.
coredata.dc:title: A theoretical study on hydrodeoxygenation of phenol over MoS2 supported single-atom Fe catalyst
